PtFe/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 catalysts were prepared using deposition and impregnation techniques and tested in water gas shift reaction in reformate-simulated feed gas. For the catalyst prepared by subsequent deposition of the metals it was observed that iron (mole ratio Pt:Fe ≈ 1.5) provides for inhibition of side reaction of methanation at the temperatures up to 350 °C. The water gas shift reaction rate per Pt surface area was also increased compared to the catalyst without iron (Pt content was the same). XPS analysis of PtFe/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 showed that there are Pt0 and Fe2+ cations on the surface in H2 atmosphere at 150–350 °C. In situ DRIFTS results demonstrated stronger CO adsorption on the Pt-support interfacial sites and higher CO2 formation rate in the gas phase going from Pt to Pt-Fe system. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Water gas shift Ceria-zirconia Platinum catalyst CO removal Hydrogen purification Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogen energy is one of the perspective ways to follow decarbonization trend of the last decades [1]. For example, hydrogen can be used as a feed gas for low-temperature proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) suggested for electricity production on board of vehicles and other mobile plants [2]. But in this case highly pure hydrogen is required. For instance, CO impurity concentration must not exceed 10 ppm to avoid poisoning of Pt-containing electrocatalysts in PEMFC [3]. To reduce CO concentration in syngas produced from methane by its steam reforming, water gas shift (WGS) reaction can be performed [4]: (1) C O + H 2 O ↔ C O 2 + H 2 Δ H 298 0 = − 41.2 kJ / mol This process makes it possible to lower CO content in hydrogen-rich gas to 1 vol. %, which allows subsequent CO methanation or preferential oxidation leading to hydrogen of required purity [5]. Last decades platinum ceria-supported catalysts are considered as perspective systems for WGS process [6,7]. Opposite to conventional Fe-Cr and Cu-Zn oxide catalysts, these ones are tolerant to oxygen traces in gas mixture and do not require a long-time activation [7]. Therefore, they are supposed to be more suitable for portable hydrogen generators. Ceria is well-known as a support for the catalysts for oxidation processes [8,9] due to its high reducibility and oxygen mobility. But undoped CeO2 has low thermal and mechanical stability [10,11]. For this reason, Zr-doped ceria is widely used as a support since it was shown that Zr positively affects these properties [11]. For ceria with ∼10–50 % of Ce atoms substituted by Zr, the increase in the specific surface area was observed compared to CeO2, which also led to the decrease in the size of supported Pt particles and, consequently, the increase in the number of the active sites [12,13]. If syngas (H2, CO and CO2 as the main components) is used as the feed gas for WGS process, the side reaction of methanation of carbon oxides could occur [14,15]: (2) C O + 3 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + H 2 O Δ r H 298 0 = − 206 kJ / mol (3) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ r H 298 0 = − 164 kJ / mol These reactions are unfavorable because of their high exothermicity leading to the higher temperature of the catalyst bed and, consequently, lower CO conversion due to thermodynamic limitations of WGS reaction [4]. Also, one can notice that 3 or 4 H2 molecules are needed to convert CO or CO2 to methane, but only one H2 molecule is formed in WGS. That means the target product – hydrogen – is being spent during the process. For this reason, the catalysts for WGS reaction should be evaluated not only in terms of their WGS activity but also selectivity towards the methanation reaction. In our previous works, we have shown that WGS process over a Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 catalyst using reformate-simulated feed gas is accompanied by this side methanation reaction [14,16]. Unfortunately, this problem is superficially investigated for this type of catalysts. For example, a few studies can be found reporting Pt-Ru [17] and Pt-Ni [18] bimetallic catalysts with improved selectivity towards WGS reaction, but both these are the cases when Pt itself was used as anti-methanation agent because Ru and Ni are highly active in this side reaction [19]. Nevertheless, this problem has acquired some attention. The studies [20,21] reported on similar approaches to inhibition of the methanation reaction over Pt/CeO2 catalysts: it was shown that encapsulation of Pt nanoparticles into ceria allows significantly reducing [21] or totally inhibiting [20] methane formation during WGS process in the reformate-simulated mixture. That way, the authors of [20] prepared 5 wt% Pt/CeO2 catalysts with “Pt core-ceria shell” type nanoparticles using microemulsion technique. Comparing with the catalysts prepared by impregnation and co-precipitation, these showed improved WGS activity and no methane formation. The authors of [21] managed to significantly inhibit methane formation without a notable decrease in CO conversion by WGS reaction. They used the incipient wet impregnation technique and three-stage thermal treatment in different atmospheres to obtain a thin (< 1 nm) layer of CeO2 over the supported Pt nanoparticles. The patent [22] claims Fe to work as anti-methanation agent for WGS platinum catalysts. Unfortunately, no studies were found proving this information. However, it has been shown recently [23] for the series of catalysts PtМ/CeO2 (M = Fe, Co, Ni) that iron allows for the most pronounced TOF increase compared to Pt/CeO2. Moreover, using Fe as the second supported metal turned out to be more effective than doping ceria with rare-earth metals [23]. Unfortunately, no information was given on the selectivity of this catalyst towards the methanation reactions. The positive effect of doping ceria with iron was reported in [24,25]. The authors have shown that introducing of both Zr and Fe into ceria lattice provides for the increase of CO conversion, better reducibility of ceria support (which means the increase of the number of “Ce3+-oxygen vacancy” sites active in WGS) and enhanced resistance toward carbon deposits of Pt/Ce0.9Zr0.05Fe0.05O2/Al2O3 compared to Pt/CeO2/Al2O3. Earlier we reported on the improved WGS activity of Pt-Fe/SiO2 catalyst compared to Pt/SiO2 [26]. In that work, we also showed the activity of Pt0.5Fe0.5 nanopowder in WGS reaction. We did not observe methane formation for these systems, but we believe this was due to their relatively low activity in general. However, all these results do show the potential of iron as an activating promoter. This, together with the data on its anti-methanation properties, makes Pt-Fe/CeO2 system interesting for more detailed study. In the present work we report on the improved WGS activity and selectivity of bimetallic PtFe/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 catalyst compared to Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2. Addition of Fe to the platinum catalyst allowed inhibition of methane formation in reformate-simulated gas, as well as the increase of the WGS reaction rate, normalized to Pt surface area. The composition and structure of the catalysts were studied using transmission electron microscopy and in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Also, in situ DRIFTS study was performed to elucidate the nature of the interaction between reagents and catalyst surface during WGS process. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation For all the catalysts prepared in this work mixed oxide Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 (Ecoalliance LLC; denoted as CZ) was used as a support. A monometallic catalyst 1.9 wt. % Pt/CZ (denoted as Pt/CZ) was prepared by sorption-hydrolytic deposition of platinum on CZ as described elsewhere [27] in details. A specified amount of CZ powder was loaded to K2PtCl4 (JSC «Krastsvetmet») aqueous solution at 25 °C. After that Na2CO3 aqueous solution (mole ratio K2PtCl4 : Na2CO3 = 1 : 1.1) was added dropwise to the suspension under stirring. The resulted mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 10 min, then – at 80 °C for 30 min. Then the slurry was filtered, washed with hot water, dried overnight and reduced in 10 vol. % H2 in Ar at 350 °C for 1 h. Pt content determined using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was 1.25 wt. %. Bimetallic catalyst 1.9 wt. % Pt-1 wt. % Fe/CZ (denoted as PtFe/CZ-dep; mole ratio Pt : Fe ≈ 1 : 1.5) was prepared by subsequent deposition of the metals on CZ. Iron was deposited first by incipient wetness impregnation by Fe(NO3)3·9H2O aqueous solution followed by the treatment in NH3 for 15 min in a desiccator. After that the sample was dried using freeze-drier and then calcined in air at 400 °C for 2 h. Then platinum was deposited according to the procedure described above. Pt and Fe contents determined using ICP-AES were 1.63 and 0.68 wt. %, respectively. Bimetallic catalyst 1.9 wt. % Pt-0.6 wt. % Fe/CZ (denoted as PtFe/CZ-DCS; mole ratio Pt : Fe = 1 : 1) was prepared by subsequent incipient wetness impregnation by aqueous solutions of the precursors of the double complex salt (DCS) [Pt(NH3)5Cl][Fe(C2O4)3]. It was shown in our previous work [26] that decomposition of this salt in H2 flow leads to the formation of Pt-Fe solid solutions. First, CZ was impregnated with [Pt(NH3)5Cl]Cl3 aqueous solution, then dried at 60 °C for 5 h. After that the sample was impregnated with (NH4)3[Fe(C2O4)3] aqueous solution, then dried at 60 °C for 5 h and reduced in the flow of 10 vol. % H2 in Ar at 450 °C for 1 h (heating rate 10 °C/min). Pt and Fe contents determined using ICP-AES were 1.67 and 0.58 wt. %, respectively. Catalyst 1.2 wt. % Fe/CZ (denoted as Fe/CZ) was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation by Fe(NO3)3·9H2O aqueous solution followed by the treatment in NH3 for 15 min in a desiccator. After that the sample was dried at 80 °C for 9 h and then calcined in air at 400 °C for 2 h. 2.2 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests of the samples were performed in quartz U-shaped tubular flow reactor (inner diameter 3 mm) at atmospheric pressure. The catalyst load was 125 mg, fraction – 0.2–0.5 mm. The composition of the feed gas (vol. %): CO – 10, CO2 – 15, H2 – 45, H2O – 30 (with the accuracy of ±0.5 vol. %); WHSV 30,000 mL·gcat -1·h-1. The temperature was controlled using K-type thermocouple placed at the midpoint of the catalyst bed. The composition of the wet inlet and outlet gases was analyzed by gas chromatograph “Crystal 5000″ (“Chromatec”, Russia) equipped with the thermal conductivity detector (NaX molecular sieves column) and flame ionization detector (Carboxen 1000 column) with a methanator sensitive to the CO, CO2 and CH4 concentrations of ∼1 ppm. The WGS reaction rate value at 250 °C was calculated using the following equation: (4) W = W H S V · X ( C O ) · [ C O ] 0 m s n s V m where WHSV = 30,000 mL·gcat -1·h-1, X(CO) – CO conversion (unit fraction), [CO]0 – initial CO concentration in the feed gas (unit fraction), ms – catalyst load used for CO chemisorption (g), ns – the number of surface sites available for CO chemisorption (the same as the quantity of CO chemisorbed) in [ms] g of the catalyst (mol), Vm = 22,400 ml/mol – molar volume of a gas. The ms and ns values are given in Table S1. The apparent activation energy was found from the slope value of the Arrhenius plot built in “ln W – 1/T” coordinates. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The supported metal surface area (defined as the amount of chemisorbed CO molecules) and CO/(Pt+Fe) molar ratio were determined by pulsed CO chemisorption. The sample was placed in a reactor, where it was reduced in a flow of H2 at 350 °C for 30 min. Then the reactor was cooled to 20 °C and a given quantity of CO was supplied in pulses, and then the quantity of CO at the outlet of the reactor was measured. From these data, the amount of adsorbed CO and CO/(Pt+Fe) molar ratio were calculated taking into account an assumption that one metal atom adsorb one CO molecule. The accuracy of CO/(Pt+Fe) determination was 10 rel. %. No CO chemisorption was observed for CZ support in these conditions. High-angle annular dark-field transmission electron microscopy (TEM-HAADF) studies with EDX mapping were carried out using Themis Z electron microscope (“Thermo Fisher Scientific”, The Netherlands) operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples for the TEM study were dispersed ultrasonically (35 kHz) using ethanol solutions and deposited on copper grids covered with a holey carbon film. XPS studies of PtFe/CZ-dep were performed using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (SPECS Surface Nano Analysis GmbH, Germany) equipped with a hemispherical electron energy analyzer PHOIBOS-150-MCD-9 and an XR-50 X-ray source with a double Al/Mg anode. Nonmonochromatic MgKα radiation (hv = 1253.6 eV) was used for acquiring the spectra. The spectrometer is equipped with a high-pressure chamber allowing the treatment of samples and their transfer to the analyzer chamber for the XPS analysis without any contact with air. The treatment conditions are described in Table 1 . The binding energy calibration was performed by setting the Ce3d3/2 -u’’’ peak at 916.7 eV. The surface elemental composition was calculated from the integral intensities of the XPS peaks with the Scofield photoionization cross-sections taken into account [28]. After background subtraction by the Shirley method the spectra were deconvoluted resulting in the peaks corresponding to the photoemission of the electrons from the atoms in different state. Curve fitting was performed with CasaXPS software [29]. The peaks were fitted with a mixed Gaussian-Lorentzian function. The samples of Pt/CZ and PtFe/CZ-dep were studied by diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) using VERTEX 80v (Bruker Optic GmbH) IR spectrometer equipped with a MCT (mercury cadmium telluride) detector, a chamber and a heating unit HARRICK for in situ DRIFTS experiments. WGS reaction was studied under 50 cm3/min feed gas flow of the following composition (vol. %): CO – 1, H2 – 4.5, He – balance. The dry gas was fed into a saturator with water at room temperature, after that the wet gas (∼3 vol. % H2O) was fed into the chamber with the catalyst. Mass flow controllers HORIBA SEC-Z500X were used to obtain the reaction gas mixture. Prior to the experiments, the catalysts were reduced in 5 % H2/He flow at 350 °C for 1 h. Then background spectra were recorded at 350, 300, 250, 200 °C in He flow (20 cm3/min). After that, the reaction mixture was fed into the in situ chamber, and the DRIFT spectra were recorded at 200, 250, 300, 350 °C for 30 min at each temperature with 4 cm-1 resolution. The final spectra were obtained by background subtraction and averaging the spectra recorded at each temperature. 3 Results and discussion The series of the supported catalysts was tested in WGS reaction in reformate-simulated mixture (Fig. 1 ). PtFe/CZ-DCS demonstrated poor activity – the equilibrium CO concentration in the outlet gas was observed only at T ≥ 350 °C (Fig. 1a). Although this catalyst may contain Cl traces (from Pt precursor) which can poison the active sites [30], we believe that chlorine concentration is too low to significantly affect the performance of the catalyst in this case. The catalyst with only Fe supported had almost no activity in WGS in these conditions. It can be clearly seen that Pt/CZ and PtFe/CZ-dep have shown similar performance in terms of outlet CO concentration (Fig. 1a), allowing reaching the equilibrium values at 325 °C. CO2 and H2 concentrations met the equilibrium values at the same temperatures (Fig. 1c,d) as CO. This indicates that CO2 and H2 are not consumed in any other reactions except methanation, the contribution of which is negligible in terms of the quantity of CO2 and H2 consumed relative to the total amount of these gases. Also, it is important to note that carbon balance was 100 ± 1 % throughout the entire temperature range, which indicates that no coke was formed on the surface of the catalysts due to Boudouir reaction. It was also proved earlier by temperature-programmed oxidation analysis of 5 wt. % Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 after WGS in our work [14]. At the same time, they differ significantly in terms of the selectivity to the side methanation reaction (Fig. 1b). In the case of Pt/CZ, methane formation was detected at T ≥ 275 °C, while there was no methane in the outlet gas up to 350 °C for PtFe/CZ-dep, and at 350 °C its concentration was much lower than for Pt/CZ (Fig. 1b). Notably, substitution of water vapor with Ar did not affect methanation over PtFe/CZ-dep: no CH4 formed at 250–350 °C (Fig. 1b), and only slight increase of CO concentration along with the decrease of CO2 and H2 concentrations because of reversed water gas shift reaction was observed. On the contrary, we reported earlier [14] on the same experiment with substitution of H2O with Ar for 5 wt. % Pt/CZ: there was more methane formed in the absence of water vapor compared to the experiment with 30 vol. % H2O in the feed gas. Therefore, one can assume that iron in PtFe/CZ-dep acts like an anti-methanation agent. Although there is no methane formation in the case of PtFe/CZ-DCS as well, we do not have a clear evidence of this effect here since this catalyst is less active in general. Two bimetallic catalysts after WGS were studied by TEM using EDX mapping. In the case of PtFe/CZ-dep supported particles are highly dispersed (Fig. 2 a, b, e). EDX mapping shows quite uniform distributions for both Pt and Fe (Fig. 2c, d). However, there is no evidence that most of the particles supported are bimetallic. For example, as can be seen in Fig. 2f, g, the particle consists of platinum predominantly. As for PtFe/CZ-DCS, EDX mapping shows that there are bimetallic particles formed on the support (Fig. 3 d-f). But we cannot claim that they are the only ones on the surface. It can be seen in Fig. 3a-c that there are particles containing Pt predominantly as it was observed for PtFe/CZ-dep. Given these results, one can conclude that using DCS precursors for CZ impregnation do not allow selective formation of bimetallic Pt-Fe on the support. We assume that the interaction of the complexes-precursors with the functional groups on the surface of the support may hinder DCS formation and, consequently, the formation of Pt-Fe bimetallic particles. Unfortunately, studying the structure of bimetallic Pt-Fe catalysts is quite complex because of the problem of determining the contribution of each metal when studying a catalyst by a method sensitive to both of them. For this reason, for Pt-Fe samples, we were able only to determine the total surface area available for CO chemisorption in terms of CO/(Pt+Fe) molar ratio, since both Pt and Fe adsorb CO at room temperature. The comparison of the results for the samples under study may be used for the rough evaluation of the surface area available for catalysis. It also should be noted that CZ without any metals supported does not adsorb detectable quantity of CO. On the other hand, in the case of Pt/CZ and PtFe/CZ the ability of CZ to chemisorb CO can change after the treatment in H2 because of the partial reduction of CZ because of hydrogen spillover [30–32]. Nevertheless, given the fact that all the samples contain a comparable quantity of the supported metals and were pre-treated in the same conditions before CO chemisorption, we assume the proportion of CO chemisorbed on CZ is practically the same for them as well. However, we cannot evaluate the total number of CZ surface sites in the catalysts, so we consider the quantity of CO chemisorbed on CZ (in case it does exist) as a constant included in the error of the obtained values. For all the above-mentioned reasons, we compare the samples in terms of CO/(Pt+Fe) molar ratio. These data are presented in Table 2 . For both the as-prepared and tested in WGS samples, it can be clearly seen that CO/(Pt+Fe) values for bimetallic catalysts are significantly lower than one for Pt/CZ. Consequently, one can assume that the Pt surface area increases in a row Pt/CZ > PtFe/CZ-dep > PtFe/CZ-DCS. According to these results, the calculated values of the reaction rate at 250 °C (with the accuracy of 10 rel. %) for Pt/CZ and PtFe/CZ-dep are 879 and 1340 molCO·molcs -1·h-1 (cs = the quantity of CO adsorbed on a catalyst in CO chemisorption experiment), respectively. Therefore, given these data and the fact Fe/CZ shows no activity in WGS at T ≤ 350 °C, we assume that Fe acts as a promotor and improves not only the selectivity of Pt/CZ towards WGS, but also the activity of the platinum catalyst in this reaction. At the same time, the WGS reaction rate over PtFe/CZ-dep turned out to be weakly depended on the CO inlet concentration. As can be seen from Fig. 4 , the values for 5 vol. % CO are slightly lower than for 10 and 15 vol. %, while for the latter two they are virtually the same in the temperature range of 230–250 °С. Therefore, we can roughly estimate the CO reaction order (nCO) to be in the range 0 < nCO < 1. The apparent activation energy (Ea) value calculated from the data of 10 % CO experiment was 85 ± 5 kJ/mol. Since both CO reaction order and Ea values correlate with the ones for the Pt/CZ reported earlier in our work [27], we assume that Fe addition to the platinum catalyst does not change the reaction mechanism. To make it clear the actual state of the PtFe/CZ-dep catalyst in the reductive atmosphere, XPS studies of the catalyst after H2 treatment were performed. The resulting spectra show the changes of oxidation states of the surface atoms in the as-prepared catalyst and after H2 treatment at 150, 250 and 350 °C. Fig. 5 a shows Zr3d spectra of PtFe/CZ-dep catalyst. The Zr3d spectrum is a doublet Zr3d5/2 – Zr3d3/2 with the ratio of the integral intensities of the components of 3:2 and the spin-orbit splitting of 2.39 eV. All the Zr3d spectra of the catalyst have one doublet with the Zr3d5/2 binding energy of 182.3 eV, which corresponds to Zr4+ state. For the stoichiometric oxide ZrO2 this value is in the range of 182.2–183.3 eV [33–36]. Fig. 5b presents Ce3d spectra of PtFe/CZ-dep catalyst. In all four cases, Ce3+ and Ce4+ states were found. As known, Ce3d spectra have a complex structure. Firstly, Ce3d level is split to the Ce3d5/2 and Ce3d3/2 components due to the spin-orbit interaction. That leads to the doublet with the ratio of the integral intensities of its components of 3:2. Secondly, each component of this doublet is split to 3 peaks in the case of CeO2 (v/u, v′′/u′′, v′′′/u′′′) or 2 peaks in the case of Ce2O3 (v′/u′, v0/u0). Measuring the relative integral intensities of these components allows evaluating Ce4+ fraction [37,38]. According to the results of the deconvolution of the spectra, the Ce4+ fraction in the sample decreases from 74 to 55 % after H2 treatment. Fig. 6 a presents Pt4f spectra of PtFe/CZ catalyst before and after H2 treatment. As Zr3d and Ce3d spectra, Pt4f level is split to the Pt4f 7/2 and Pt4f 5/2 components with the spin-orbit splitting energy of 3.33 eV. The spectrum of the catalyst before H2 treatment is approximated by two doublets: an asymmetric doublet Pt4f 7/2–Pt4f 5/2 with Pt4f 7/2 binding energy of 71.1 eV and a symmetric doublet Pt4f 7/2–Pt4f 5/2 with a Pt4f 7/2 binding energy of 72.4 eV. In the literature, for bulk metallic platinum, the Pt4f 7/2 binding energy is about 71.1–71.2 eV [39,40]. In turn, for bulk PtO, PtO2 and Pt(OH)4 these values are in the range of 72.3–73.0 eV, 74.0–74.1 eV and 74.2–74.4 eV [41–44], respectively. Thus, it can be concluded that on the catalyst surface before H2 treatment platinum exists in Pt0 and Pt2+ states. H2 treatment at 150 °C leads to the reduction of platinum to Pt0 state (only one asymmetric doublet Pt4f 7/2–Pt4f 5/2 with the Pt4f 7/2 binding energy of 71.1 eV is observed). In the case of further treatment in H2 at higher temperatures, platinum is also in the metallic state. It is interesting to note that the authors of [23] detected the increase of the concentration of Pt2+ in PtFe/CeO2 compared to Pt/CeO2 after the treatment in WGS reaction mixture (CO+H2O+He). Unfortunately, since we used pure H2 for XPS analysis, we were not able to observe this effect. Fig. 6b shows the Fe2p spectra of PtFe/CZ catalyst. As one can see, Fe2p spectra have the form of doublet Fe2p3/2 –Fe2p1/2 with the ratio of the integral intensities of its components of 2:1. All the spectra can be described by one Fe2p3/2 –Fe2p1/2 doublet. In the case of the as-prepared PtFe/CZ-dep catalyst, Fe2p3/2 binding energy is about 711.2 eV, while H2 treatment at 350 °C led to the decrease of this value to 709.2 eV. This indicates reduction of the Fe cations on the surface of PtFe/CZ catalyst. In fact, according to the reported data, for Fe cations in FeO, Fe3O4, Fe2O3 and FeOOH Fe2p3/2 binding energy is in the ranges of 709.5–710.2, 710.1–710.6, 710.7–711.2 and 710.7–711.2 eV, respectively [45–48]. Therefore, one can conclude that iron is in Fe3+ state on the surface in the case of the as-prepared catalyst, while H2 treatment leads to their reduction to Fe2+ state. Table S2 summarizes the information on the observed binding energies for Pt, Fe, Ce and Zr cations in PtFe/CZ-dep catalyst during XPS analysis. One can see that the value for Fe2+ slightly decreases from 709.6 to 709.2 eV with the increase of the treatment temperature and goes off the range of the characteristic binding energies of FeO (709.5–710.2 eV) to the lower values. This may indicate that higher temperature of H2 treatment allows reduction to Fe(2-δ)+ state and formation of FeO1-x phase with the high concentration of oxygen vacancies. Therefore, given the fact that platinum and iron are in Pt0 and Fe(2-δ)+ states, respectively, we can conclude that these metals exist on the surface of the support predominantly as individual monometallic phases. The surface ratios and concentrations of the elements in PtFe/CZ-dep are presented in Table 3 . One can notice the slight decrease of [Pt]/([Ce]+[Zr]) and [Fe]/([Ce]+[Zr]) surface ratios with the increase of the temperature of hydrogen treatment; observed decrease is due to the reduction of Pt and Fe cations accompanied with the increase in size of Pt and Fe particles. Indeed, it has been found that for oxide support the reduction of deposited active component leads to decrease in [M]/[Support] ratio due to the increase in size of particles of active component, it was observed for Ni/CeZrOx catalyst [49], V/TiO2 [50], on the contrary, the oxidizing treatment leads to increase in [M]/[Support] ratio due to the spreading or flattening of the supported particles – Pd/Al2O3 [51]or V/TiO2 [50]. For PtFe/CZ-dep catalysts at 150 °C Pt2+ is fully reduced to the metallic state when Fe3+ is reduced only to Fe2+ state (Table S2). The further increase in temperature leads to more extensive increase in size for Fe particles than for Pt particles that is clear in Table 3. The fluctuation of [Fe]/[Pt] ratio is the result of this process. The decrease of the surface oxygen concentration can also be observed. On the one hand, this may be partly because of the desorption of CO2 (it is known that carbonates form on the surface of CeO2 when in contact with air [52,53]) and/or sintering of FeOx phase. But, on the other hand, this correlates with the decrease of Ce4+ concentration, which, in turn, means the increase of Ce3+ concentration and associated oxygen vacancies. These vacancies (Ov) are known to be a part of the active sites Pt‒Ov‒Ce3+ in Pt/CeO2 catalysts [54–57]. As it has been early reported in [30], this partial reduction of the oxide support is due to the presence of Pt0 nanoparticles initiating hydrogen spillover. Given this fact, it is also interesting to note that the concentrations of the surface Ce3+ atoms in PtFe/CZ-dep and 5 wt. % Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 (the same support) [14,30]after H2 treatment at 350 °C are comparable – 45 and 41 [14] or 48 [30] %, respectively – despite the difference in Pt content (but comparable Pt particle size). Therefore, we can conclude that the increase in Pt content does not lead to the proportional increase in the concentration of Ce3+ cations and oxygen vacancies on the surface of the support. As it was mentioned earlier, iron exists only in the oxidized form on the surface of PtFe/CZ-dep even in the reductive atmosphere. For this reason, we assume that iron oxide may play a role similar to the one of Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 in the catalysis of WGS reaction, providing for oxygen vacancies. It is also should be noted that Fe3O4 catalyzes high-temperature WGS process (300–500 °C) via redox mechanism [58–60]. So, this reaction path may be enabled by iron oxide on the surface of PtFe/CZ-dep in the case the reaction conditions allow for formation of the phase capable of Fe2+↔Fe3+ transitions. In order to get more information on the WGS reaction route over PtFe/CZ-dep catalyst, DRIFTS study was performed for this catalyst and also for Pt/CZ as well. Fig. 7 a presents the spectra for Pt/CZ obtained at 200, 250, 300 and 350 °C. The bands corresponding to formate species on the surface of the catalyst are observed at all temperatures [61–66]. The intensities of these bands significantly increase with temperature. The bands corresponding to gaseous CO2 (WGS product) are also observed [64,67]. A few bands corresponding to CO adsorbed on Pt metal sites were found in the range of 2070–1800 cm-1 [57,68–71]. Also, numerous overlapping bands are observed in the region of 1700–850 cm-1, which correspond to different forms of carbonates adsorbed on the Ce0.75Zr0.25O2. The bands can be distinguished that can be attributed to monodentate or bidentate carbonates [62,64,65,72–74]. All detected bands and their assignments are given in Table 4 . Fig. 7b presents DRIFT spectra for PtFe/CZ-dep sample at 200, 250, 300 and 350 °C. The bands corresponding to formate species are observed at all temperatures as well as in the case of Pt/CZ catalyst [61–66]. The intensities of these bands also significantly increase with temperature. At the same time, the bands characteristic to CH bond in formate species (Table 4) are blue-shifted compared to the ones of Pt/CZ, while the bands characteristic to only OC-O bonds in formate are of the same frequencies. In principle, the PtFe/CZ-dep spectra are characterized by the same set of bands as the spectra of Pt/CZ (Table 4). However, there is a difference in the frequencies of CO adsorbed on Pt metal sites. As can be seen from Table 4, high-frequency Pt-CO band is red-shifted in PtFe/CZ-dep spectra compared to the ones of Pt/CZ. These bands were reported to be characteristic of CO adsorbed on high coordinated Pt atoms. For both catalysts, this band is being blue-shifted with the increase of the reaction temperature (insets on Fig 7a,b). On the contrary, low-frequency Pt-CO bands are blue-shifted going from Pt to Pt-Fe system. Since low-frequency bands are associated with CO bonded to low coordinated Pt atoms in proximal contact with reduced Ce3+ sites along the metal−support interface [57] where the active sites are located, one can conclude that CO adsorption on the active site is stronger in the case of PtFe/CZ-dep. Despite the results of the static in situ DRIFTS analysis are not enough to make solid conclusions on the mechanism of WGS reaction, we believe that they can be useful for further studies of the WGS reaction mechanism over bimetallic Pt-Fe catalysts. In general, one can conclude that doping platinum catalyst with iron leads to changes in the nature of the interaction of the reagents with the catalyst, which, apparently, has a positive effect on the activity and selectivity of PtFe/CZ-dep in WGS reaction. 4 Conclusion The influence of Fe addition as a second supported metal to 1.6 wt. % Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 on the activity in the water gas shift reaction and selectivity to the side reaction of the methanation of carbon oxides was studied. For the Pt-Fe catalyst prepared by the subsequent deposition of the metals, the inhibition of methane formation was observed at temperatures up to 350 °C in the reformate-simulated feed gas. The water gas shift reaction rate, normalized to Pt surface area, also increased for almost 50 % compared to 1.25 wt. % Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2. XPS study of Pt-Fe catalyst revealed that there are Pt0 and Fe2+ on the surface of the catalyst in H2 atmosphere at 150–350 °C. The comparison of in situ DRIFTS results showed stronger CO adsorption on the Pt-support interfacial sites, higher CO2 formation rate and change in the balance between carbonate and carboxylate species going from Pt to Pt-Fe system. Based on the results obtained in this study, one can conclude that Fe affects positively both activity and selectivity of Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 in the water gas shift reaction, although does not change the reaction mechanism, but only facilitates its individual stages. coredata.dc:description: PtFe/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 catalysts were prepared using deposition and impregnation techniques and tested in water gas shift reaction in reformate-simulated feed gas. For the catalyst prepared by subsequent deposition of the metals it was observed that iron (mole ratio Pt:Fe ≈ 1.5) provides for inhibition of side reaction of methanation at the temperatures up to 350 °C. The water gas shift reaction rate per Pt surface area was also increased compared to the catalyst without iron (Pt content was the same). XPS analysis of PtFe/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 showed that there are Pt0 and Fe2+ cations on the surface in H2 atmosphere at 150–350 °C. In situ DRIFTS results demonstrated stronger CO adsorption on the Pt-support interfacial sites and higher CO2 formation rate in the gas phase going from Pt to Pt-Fe system.
